choices.text: Clostridium tetani
Clostridium perfringens
Clostridium difficile
Neisseria meningitidis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the clinic exhibiting lockjaw (trismus) and opisthotonus, a condition where the back becomes extremely arched. These symptoms are characteristic of an infection with what organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clostridium tetani. 

 

Option A:

 

These symptoms are indicative of tetanus, which is caused by the neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Clostridium perfringens is associated with gas gangrene and food poisoning but not with tetanus.

 

Option C: Clostridium difficile causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis, not tetanus.

 

Option D: Neisseria meningitidis causes meningococcal meningitis, leading to symptoms like fever, headache, stiff neck, and in severe cases, a purpuric rash. It does not cause the neuromuscular symptoms associated with tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of tetanus, including trismus and opisthotonos, is characteristic of Clostridium tetani as the causative organism.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p261, 2/e p271

choices.text: By inhibiting the release of GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid)
By inhibiting cyclic AMP (cAMP)
By inactivating acetylcholine (ACh) receptors
By inhibiting cyclic GMP (cGMP)

questions.text: A medical student is studying the pathophysiology of tetanus. She is trying to understand the mechanism of action of the tetanospasmin toxin. How does tetanospasmin contribute to the clinical features of tetanus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) By inhibiting the release of GABA. 

 

Option A:

 

Tetanospasmin, a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani, prevents the release of neurotransmitters GABA and glycine from inhibitory neurons in the central nervous system, which leads to muscle rigidity and spasms characteristic of tetanus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Inhibition of cAMP is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin.

 

Option C: Tetanospasmin does not inactivate acetylcholine receptors; instead, it prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters in the central nervous system.

 

Option D: Inhibition of cGMP is not related to the action of tetanospasmin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mechanism of action of tetanospasmin, involves the inhibition of inhibitory neurotransmitter release, leading to the characteristic hyperactivity of muscle fibers seen in tetanus.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p261, 2/e p271, Ananthanarayan 9/e p262, 10/e p265

choices.text: The causative organism produces heat-resistant spores.
The disease does not spread from person to person.
The typical incubation period for tetanus is 6–10 days.
Three doses of primary vaccination provide protection against tetanus.

questions.text: During an infectious disease rotation, a medical resident is quizzed on various aspects of tetanus. Which of the following statements about tetanus is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The typical incubation period for tetanus is 6–10 days. 

 

Option C:

 

This statement is false as the incubation period for tetanus can vary widely, from 3 days to several weeks, but the average is typically longer than 6–10 days.

Most cases occur within 14 days.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True, Clostridium tetani produces heat-resistant spores, which can survive in the environment for long periods.

 

Option B: True, tetanus cannot be transmitted from person to person; it is acquired through environmental exposure to the spores of the bacterium.

 

Option D: True, three doses of the primary tetanus vaccination series generally provide protective immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incubation period for tetanus, caused by Clostridium tetani, can vary widely, usually ranging from 3 days to several weeks, with an average of about 10 days. C. tetani does produce heat-resistant spores, tetanus is not contagious (i.e., it does not spread from person to person), and three doses of primary vaccination do provide protection against tetanus.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p263, 2/e p273

choices.text: Administer a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster
Administer human tetanus immune globulin
Prescribe broad-spectrum antibiotics
Perform wound cleaning

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy with a history of complete primary immunization and a booster given 6 years ago is brought to the emergency room with a contaminated wound on his left leg from a road traffic accident. Which of the following interventions is NOT indicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer human tetanus immune globulin. 

 

The patient had complete primary immunization and a booster 6 years ago.
 

For contaminated wounds, TT booster is indicated if last dose was >5 years ago, but immunoglobulin is not needed if the patient has had ≥3 doses of tetanus vaccine.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A: Administer a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster: Needed as last immunization was 6 Years ago.

 

Option C: Prescribe broad-spectrum antibiotics: Indicated for contaminated wound to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Perform wound debridement and cleaning: This is a first-line step in all tetanus-prone wounds — removes necrotic tissue and dirt.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevention of Tetanus in Wound

 

Where,

 

A. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5 years

 

B. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5-10 years

 

C. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in >10 years ago

 

D. Has not had a complete course of toxoid or status is unknown.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p262, 2/e p273, Park 23/e p312, 24/e p330

choices.text: The underlying skin and muscles typically appear normal.
It is caused by the tetanospasmin toxin.
The condition is characterized by muscle rigidity and spasms.
The most commonly implicated organism in gas gangrene is Clostridium perfringens.

questions.text: A trauma patient is admitted to the hospital with concerns for gas gangrene due to a deep, necrotizing wound sustained in a farming accident. Which of the following statements is correct regarding gas gangrene?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The most commonly implicated organism in gas gangrene is Clostridium perfringens. 

 

Option D:

 

C. perfringens, particularly type A, is the most frequent cause of gas gangrene, a severe form of necrotizing soft tissue infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: False, in gas gangrene, there is often severe damage to the skin and muscles, which is not normal.

 

Option B: False, gas gangrene is not caused by tetanospasmin toxin, which is associated with tetanus, not gas gangrene.

 

Option C: False, muscle rigidity and spasms are more characteristic of tetanus; gas gangrene typically causes severe pain, swelling, and production of gas.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas gangrene, also known as clostridial myonecrosis, is most commonly caused by Clostridium perfringens, a gram-positive, anaerobic bacterium. This condition often results from deep, traumatic wounds, especially in environments contaminated with soil or feces where the bacteria are commonly found. Gas gangrene is characterized by rapid tissue necrosis, gas production in tissues, and systemic toxicity. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt surgical and medical intervention.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p258, 2/e p268, Ananthanarayan 9/e p254, 10/e p262

choices.text: Clean the wound and administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid.
Clean the wound and administer Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin (Tet Ig) along with a single dose of tetanus toxoid.
Clean the wound and initiate a complete course of tetanus toxoid vaccination.
Clean the wound without additional immunization.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a minor, uncontaminated wound. His last tetanus booster was 6 years ago. For prophylaxis against tetanus, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clean the wound and administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. 

 

Option A: 

 

For adults who have completed the primary tetanus vaccine series and have a clean, minor wound, a booster dose is recommended if it has been more than 5 years since the last dose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin along with tetanus toxoid is given in the case of a major wound, especially if the patient has an unknown vaccination history or has not completed the primary vaccination series.

 

Option C: A complete course of tetanus toxoid is not necessary if the patient has previously completed the series and the wound is minor.

 

Option D: No additional immunization is generally not recommended unless the wound is minor and the last tetanus booster was within the last 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevention of Tetanus in Wound

 

 

Where,

 

A. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5 years

B. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5-10 years

C. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in >10 years ago

D. Has not had a complete course of toxoid or status is unknown.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p273, Park’s 24/e p331

choices.text: At the presynaptic terminals of inhibitory neurons in the spinal cord
At the postsynaptic terminals of neurons in the spinal cord
At the neuromuscular junction
Directly on the muscle fibers

questions.text: A neurologist is explaining the pathophysiology of tetanus to her students. She asks them to identify the primary site of action for tetanus toxin. Where does tetanus toxin predominantly exert its effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At the presynaptic terminals of inhibitory neurons in the spinal cord. 

 

Option A:

 

Tetanus toxin, tetanospasmin, binds to the presynaptic membranes of inhibitory neurons, specifically those that release glycine and GABA, leading to the characteristic muscle spasms of tetanus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Tetanospasmin does not work on the postsynaptic terminals in the spinal cord.

 

Option C: Tetanospasmin affects neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system, not directly at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Option D: The toxin does not act directly on muscle fibers but rather affects the neurons that control muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus toxin acts at the presynaptic terminals of inhibitory neurons in the spinal cord, preventing the release of neurotransmitters necessary for muscle relaxation.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p261, 2/e p271, Ananthanarayan 9/e p261,10/e p265

choices.text: It is caused by a Gram-negative spore-forming organism.
It involves toxins such as Telanolysin and Tetanospasmin.
Early signs of the disease include trismus and neck stiffness.
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures can occur with hyperstimulation in tetanus.

questions.text: In a clinical teaching session, the attending physician discusses tetanus with the residents. Which of the following statements about tetanus is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early signs of the disease include trismus and neck stiffness. 

 

Option C:

 

These are classic initial signs of tetanus, often leading to the condition being referred to as "lockjaw."

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: False, the organism that causes tetanus, Clostridium tetani, is a Gram-positive bacillus.

 

Option B: While Tetanospasmin is a toxin produced by C. tetani, Telanolysin is not commonly associated with tetanus.

 

Option D: While spasms are characteristic of tetanus, generalized tonic-clonic seizures are not a standard description.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trismus and neck stiffness is the early signs of tetanus, and these classic initial signs of tetanus, often leading to the condition known as "lockjaw." 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p261, 2/e p271-272, Ananthanarayan 9/e p261, 10/e p265

choices.text: Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis (DTaP) vaccine only
DTaP vaccine along with Tetanus Immunoglobulin (Ig)
Adult formulation of tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine only
Td vaccine along with Tetanus Immunoglobulin (Ig)

questions.text: A young man with an unknown vaccination history presents to the emergency department with multiple deep wounds and abrasions. What is the most appropriate prophylactic treatment to administer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Td vaccine along with Tetanus Immunoglobulin (Ig). 

 

Option D:

 

For adults with an unknown or incomplete vaccination history who present with a deep or contaminated wound, the CDC recommends administering both tetanus immunoglobulin and the Td vaccine for immediate and long-term protection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DTaP is typically given to children, and the adult formulation (Td or Tdap) is recommended for adults.

 

Option B: While DTaP + Ig can be considered, the adult formulation (Td or Tdap) is typically used for wound management in adults.

 

Option C: The Td vaccine alone without Ig might not provide immediate protection against tetanus in a person with unknown immunization status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevention of Tetanus in Wound

 

 

Where,

 

A. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5 years

 

B. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5-10 years

 

C. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in >10 years ago

 

D. Has not had a complete course of toxoid or status is unknown.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p263, 2/e p272

choices.text: Initiate a new full course of tetanus toxoid vaccination
Administer a booster dose of tetanus toxoid
Administer Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG)
Administer Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG) and a booster dose of tetanus toxoid

questions.text: A fully immunized individual against tetanus 10 years prior presents with a minor, clean wound. What is the most appropriate tetanus prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer a booster dose of tetanus toxoid. 

 

Option B:

 

For individuals with a complete primary immunization who sustain a clean, minor wound, a booster dose of tetanus toxoid is recommended if more than 10 years have elapsed since the last dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevention of Tetanus in Wound

 

 

 

Where,

 

A. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5 years

 

B. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in previous 5-10 years

 

C. Complete course of toxoid or booster dose in >10 years ago

 

D. Has not had a complete course of toxoid or status is unknown.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p263, 2/e p273, Park 23/e p314, 24/e p330

choices.text: The main reservoir for Clostridium tetani is soil, as well as human and animal intestines.
The most common mode of transmission is through trauma and contaminated wounds.
Herd immunity is not a useful concept for tetanus prevention.
The most common season for tetanus cases is winter and in dry conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Clostridium tetani?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The most common season for tetanus cases is winter and in dry conditions.

 

Option D:

 

Tetanus is not seasonal; it can occur at any time of the year when conditions allow for contamination of wounds with spores.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, B, and C: all 3 statements are correct 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus cases do not have a specific seasonal pattern like some other infectious diseases. The occurrence of tetanus is more related to the exposure to Clostridium tetani spores, which are ubiquitous in the environment, especially in soil, and not particularly influenced by seasonal changes. 

 

Clostridium tetani's main reservoirs include soil and the intestines of humans and animals; the bacterium is typically transmitted through contaminated wounds; and herd immunity is not applicable to tetanus prevention since it is not a contagious disease.

 

Ref: Park 23/e p312, 24/e p330

questions.text: A medical student is studying infectious diseases and wants to clarify the period of communicability for tetanus. What is the period of communicability for tetanus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) There is no period of communicability. 

 

Option D:

 

Tetanus is not contagious and cannot be transmitted from person to person. It is acquired through environmental exposure to the spores of Clostridium tetani.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus is not a communicable disease and does not have a period of communicability.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p263, 2/e p271, Park 23/e p312, 24/e p329
